department: Chinese, South and Southeast Asian Art
description: green glaze; wide circular mouth tapering to a thick neck and a globular body; appears to have three tiny feet; several rows of small incised triangles and lines on neck and body; butterfly-like raised element above ceramic ring on body
medium: Red earthenware with green and yellow glaze
text: The earliest lead glazed pottery has been found in the tombs of middle Western Han (c. 100 b.c.). This was a revolutionary ware in that it marked the beginning of controlled, colored glazes, primarily the colors green, yellow, and brown. This <I>hu<I> takes the form of a bronze vessel complete with molded <I>t'ao-tieh<I> mask handles affixed with rings. The second <I>hu<I>, shown to the left, is brown glazed and molded with a lively hunting scene around its shoulder. The shapes and lead glaze colors seen here are typical of Han storage jars made for burial.
title: Hu Storage Jar
